articles.headline: Why So Glum? Numbers Point to a Recovery
articles.snippet: The signs are that the U.S. economic recovery is growing stronger. So why do so many seem not to believe it?
articles.abstract: The signs are that the U.S. economic recovery is growing stronger. So why do so many seem not to believe it?
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy appears to be in a cyclical recovery that is gaining strength. Firms have begun to hire and consumer spending seems to be accelerating.

articles.headline: Apple Edges Into Selling of App Ads
articles.snippet: The new service will offer ways to develop interactive ads in apps for the iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch.
articles.abstract: The new service will offer ways to develop interactive ads in apps for the iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Apple, the maker of popular gadgets, is getting into the business of selling advertising, ratcheting up its rivalry with Google.

articles.headline: As Greek Bond Rates Soar, Bankruptcy Looms
articles.snippet: With rates at Greek bonds reaching 7.5 percent, the cost of insuring against a default hit a record high.
articles.abstract: With rates at Greek bonds reaching 7.5 percent, the cost of insuring against a default hit a record high.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As interest rates on Greek debt spiral upward again, the question facing Europe is no longer whether Athens has the political will to cut spending and raise taxes to curb its gaping budget deficit, but whether Greece will run out of money before it gets the chance to do so.

articles.headline: Speed Control a Small Factor in Car Claims
articles.snippet: The number of claims involving speed control was small compared to reports that listed air bags as a problem.
articles.abstract: The number of claims involving speed control was small compared to reports that listed air bags as a problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: An analysis of consumer claims submitted to auto manufacturers in recent years shows that speed-control issues — like those that have led to the recall of millions of Toyota vehicles — account for a small percentage of the possible problems brought to the attention of carmakers.
articles.byline: By Jo Craven McGinty and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Miners’ Lives: Security, but Never Peace of Mind
articles.snippet: The deaths of at least 25 miners have not affected the pride, resignation and economics that define a miner’s life.
articles.abstract: The deaths of at least 25 miners have not affected the pride, resignation and economics that define a miner’s life.
articles.lead_paragraph: HORSE CREEK, W.Va. — As Janice Quarles waited for the phone to ring with news that her husband’s body had been pulled from the Upper Big Branch mine, she vowed — much as so many West Virginia mothers have before her — that her son, Trevor, 11, would never follow his father into the mines.

articles.headline: United Chief on 3rd Verse of Old Tune
articles.snippet: Glenn F. Tilton is seeking once more to find salvation for his company in a tie-up with a competing airline. But is he just trying to make the best of a weak hand?
articles.abstract: Glenn F. Tilton is seeking once more to find salvation for his company in a tie-up with a competing airline. But is he just trying to make the best of a weak hand?
articles.lead_paragraph: When Glenn F. Tilton took the helm at United Airlines eight years ago, he inherited an airline that was fighting for its life.

articles.headline: No Survivors Found After West Virginia Mine Disaster
articles.snippet: Rescue workers failed to find any survivors after a huge explosion on Monday left 29 dead in the worst U.S. mine disaster in decades.
articles.abstract: Rescue workers failed to find any survivors after a huge explosion on Monday left 29 dead in the worst U.S. mine disaster in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTCOAL, W.Va. — An agonizing four-day wait came to a tragic end early Saturday morning when rescue workers failed to find any survivors in an underground mine after a huge explosion earlier this week.

articles.headline: Russia Calls for Halt on U.S. Adoptions
articles.snippet: The proposal was in response to a scandal over a boy who was sent back to Moscow by his adoptive mother in Tennessee.
articles.abstract: The proposal was in response to a scandal over a boy who was sent back to Moscow by his adoptive mother in Tennessee.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The boy was only 7, but he walked off the plane that arrived in Moscow from Washington all alone, carrying a knapsack with magic markers and candy, along with a single typewritten note. It was from a woman in Tennessee who had adopted him in Russia last year, became overwhelmed by what she described as his emotional problems and now wanted nothing more to do with him. Take him back, the note said.

articles.headline: Europe Said to Firm Up Terms of Greek Loans
articles.snippet: An E.U. official confirmed reports that an accord had been struck on the technical details of a possible loan for Greece.
articles.abstract: An E.U. official confirmed reports that an accord had been struck on the technical details of a possible loan for Greece.
articles.lead_paragraph: European Union officials firmed up plans on Friday to keep Greece from going off a financial cliff, as deputy finance ministers outlined terms to help the country borrow at below market rates.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Stevens’s Retirement Is Political Test for Obama
articles.snippet: The leading candidates to replace Justice John Paul Stevens present a spectrum of ideological reputations, and the choice will shape the Senate confirmation battle.
articles.abstract: The leading candidates to replace Justice John Paul Stevens present a spectrum of ideological reputations, and the choice will shape the Senate confirmation battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The announcement by Justice John Paul Stevens on Friday that he would retire at the end of this term gives President Obama the rare opportunity to make back-to-back appointments to the Supreme Court during the first two years of his presidency.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Charlie Savage
